aws::graph::propositions: # Cirrus Airplane Emergency Landing Incident
The airplane was on a west-southwest course at 15,900 feet mean sea level until 1423:49.
The final radar data point was recorded at 1423:51.
The final radar data point had an associated altitude of 15,400 feet mean sea level.
The pilot informed the air traffic controller of light icing conditions at 1421:07.
The air traffic controller noted this was the first icing report in that vicinity.
There had been earlier reports of light to moderate icing about 50 miles west of the airplane's position.
The pilot declared an emergency at 1423:52.
The pilot advised that he had "pulled the parachute" 13 seconds after declaring an emergency.
The pilot subsequently informed the air traffic controller that he had "lost control."
No further communications were received from the pilot after informing about loss of control.
The pilot reported there were no failures or malfunctions associated with the airplane prior to the incident.
A postaccident examination revealed minor damage to the landing gear.
A postaccident examination revealed minor damage to the engine cowling.
A postaccident examination revealed minor damage to the right wingtip.
Effects on the airframe due to Cirrus Airframe Parachute System (CAPS) deployment alone consisted of minor damage.
The closest weather reporting facility was at the Aspen-Pitkin County Airport (ASE).
Aspen-Pitkin County Airport (ASE) is located about 19 miles north of the incident site.
Aspen-Pitkin County Airport (ASE) is at an elevation of 7,838 feet.
Weather conditions were recorded at Aspen-Pitkin County Airport (ASE) at 1453.

text:
Radar track data depicted the airplane on a west-southwest course at 15,900 feet msl until 1423:49 (hhmm:ss). The final radar data point was recorded at 1423:51, with an associated altitude of 15,400 feet msl. A review of air traffic control communications revealed that the pilot initially informed the controller of light icing conditions at 1421:07. The controller noted that this was the first icing report in that vicinity; although there had been earlier reports of light to moderate icing about 50 miles west of the airplane's position. The pilot declared an emergency at 1423:52, and 13 seconds later he advised that he had "pulled the parachute." He subsequently informed the controller that he had "lost control." No further communications were received from the pilot.

The pilot reported that there were no failures or malfunctions associated with the airplane prior to the incident. A postaccident examination revealed minor damage to the landing gear, engine cowling, and right wingtip. Effects on the airframe due to CAPS deployment alone consisted of minor damage.

The closest weather reporting facility was at the Aspen-Pitkin County Airport (ASE), located about 19 miles north of the incident site at an elevation of 7,838 feet. At 1453, the recorded weather conditions
